sources.name: INCOSE Guide to Writing Requirements V4 Summary Sheet
sources.confidence_description: Credible source, not independently verified
sources.notes: Official INCOSE GtWR v4 - 49 attributes (A-series) with starred mandatory set, 14 characteristics (C-series), requirement types. PDF not directly accessible.

sources.name: SEBoK System Requirements Definition
sources.confidence_description: Verified via authoritative source with citation
sources.notes: SEBoK authoritative source: needs-to-requirements transformation steps, five requirement categories (Function/Performance, Fit/Operational, Form, Quality, Compliance), TBD/TBR definitions and TBX management process, transformation analysis methods

sources.name: NASA Appendix C: How to Write a Good Requirement
sources.confidence_description: Verified via authoritative source with citation
sources.notes: NASA SE Handbook Appendix C: TBD vs TBR definitions, TBR tracking elements (best estimate, rationale, action plan, responsible party, target date), requirement categories checklist (functional, performance, interface, environment, facility, training, personnel, operability, safety, security, appearance, physical)

sources.name: INCOSE Needs and Requirements Manual Section 15 - Attributes
sources.confidence_description: Credible source, not independently verified
sources.notes: NRM Section 15 covers attribute categories: define needs/requirements and intent, V&V attributes, management attributes, applicability/reuse attributes, product line management. Key attributes: Rationale, Status, Criticality, Priority, Stability, Responsible Person/Owner, Trace to Source, Trace to Parent.

sources.name: INCOSE Guide to Writing Requirements V4 Summary Sheet
sources.confidence_description: Credible source, not independently verified
sources.notes: GtWR v4 summary sheet with 49 attributes, 42 rules, 15 characteristics. Binary PDF not extractable but partial attribute list found through secondary sources: A01-Rationale, A08-V&V Method, A10-V&V Level, A15-Unique ID, A16-Unique Name, A28-Verification Status, A30-Status, A34-Priority, A38-Key/Driving, A40-Type. Starred attributes indicate mandatory minimum set.

sources.name: Digital Requirements Engineering with INCOSE-Derived MBSR (arXiv 2410.21288)
sources.confidence_description: Verified via authoritative source with citation
sources.notes: Academic paper implementing all 49 GtWR attributes in SysML model. Confirms: 49 A-series attributes, asterisk notation for mandatory set, requirement type as non-standard SysML attribute requiring customization, attributes grouped by rationale/V&V/priority/traceability/status/type.

sources.name: PPI Systems Engineering FAQ: Requirement Type Significance
sources.confidence_description: Credible source, not independently verified
sources.notes: PPI FAQ on requirement type taxonomy: states/modes, functional, performance, external interface, environmental, resource, physical, quality, design constraint. Referenced but body content not extractable from page rendering.

sources.name: Innoslate AI Tools for Requirements Gathering
sources.confidence_description: Credible source, not independently verified
sources.notes: Innoslate/Spec Innovations: Requirements AI generates candidate requirements from concept description. Three workflows: new requirements, sibling requirements, child requirements (decomposition). INCOSE GtWR aligned. Model-based derivation from functional analysis.

sources.name: INCOSE Needs and Requirements Manual (NRM) Section 6 Overview
sources.confidence_description: Credible source, not independently verified
sources.notes: INCOSE NRM describes formal transformation of needs into requirements. Requirement statement is 'result of a formal transformation of one or more needs or parent requirements into an agreed-to obligation for an entity to perform some function or possess some quality within specified constraints.' Stages: CONOPS/Goals -> Integrated Set of Needs -> Design Input Requirements -> Design Output Requirements -> System of Interest.

sources.name: Claude Code Agent Skills Best Practices (Anthropic)
sources.confidence_description: Verified via authoritative source with citation
sources.notes: Authoritative Anthropic skill-authoring guide: progressive disclosure via file references, metered questioning (max 4 questions then checkpoint), conditional workflow pattern, checklist workflow pattern, 500-line SKILL.md limit, AskUserQuestion for guided multi-step flows.

sources.name: Claude Code Agent Skills Overview (Anthropic)
sources.confidence_description: Verified via authoritative source with citation
sources.notes: Anthropic Skills overview: three-level loading (metadata/instructions/resources), progressive disclosure architecture, Level 3 resources loaded on demand, SKILL.md body under 5k tokens, references to external files loaded as needed.

sources.name: Claude Code AskUserQuestion Tool Guide (SmartScope)
sources.confidence_description: Credible source, not independently verified
sources.notes: AskUserQuestion patterns: pause-and-clarify workflow, ~10 clarification questions before execution, decision-tree questioning for type-by-type flows, progressive disclosure during execution, 60-second timeout.

sources.name: SEBoK System Requirements Definition
sources.confidence_description: Verified via authoritative source with citation
sources.notes: SEBoK categorizes requirements into 5 types: Function/Performance (primary functions), Fit/Operational (secondary/integration capabilities), Form (physical characteristics), Quality (ilities), Compliance (standards). Transformation from needs employs functional analysis, interface analysis, data flow diagrams, performance analysis. Process is iterative and recursive alongside architecture definition.

sources.name: Claude Code Skills Multi-Round Interview Pattern (neonwatty.com)
sources.confidence_description: Credible source, not independently verified
sources.notes: Multi-round AskUserQuestion interview pattern: explore-first, 5-10 rounds of questioning, non-obvious questions to surface hidden assumptions, gate-on-approval before execution, organic follow-up emergence. Progressive topic sequencing across rounds.

sources.name: NASA Common Leading Indicators: TBD/TBR Burndown
sources.confidence_description: Verified via authoritative source with citation
sources.notes: NASA metric: TBD/TBR tracked as burndown plot against planned closure rate. TBDs/TBRs present significant impact to designs, verifications, manufacturing, operations. Tracked as percent growth, TBD/TBR closures, number of requirement changes.

sources.name: PPI Requirements Writing Patterns - Issuu
sources.confidence_description: Credible source, not independently verified
sources.notes: PPI Parsing Template nine-element structure: Actor, Conditions for Action, Action (shall), three Constraint positions, Object of Action, Refinement of Object, Exception to Action. Also surveys 12+ competing patterns: EARS, ISO 29148, Planguage, Boeing-Carson, PABRE.

sources.name: Innoslate Requirements AI - Spec Innovations Help
sources.confidence_description: Verified via authoritative source with citation
sources.notes: Innoslate Requirements AI transforms needs into INCOSE GtWR v4-aligned requirements via 3-phase process: (1) Setup - user provides context/parent requirement, (2) Configure - user sets quantity sliders for parent/child counts, (3) Verify & Create - review generated requirements before saving. Generates 7 requirement categories: Functional, Environmental, Interface, Performance, Reliability, Safety, Verification. Each requirement includes name, statement, rationale, classification. Also supports expansion (sibling/child generation).

sources.name: EARS Easy Approach to Requirements Syntax (Alistair Mavin)
sources.confidence_description: Verified via authoritative source with citation
sources.notes: EARS five requirement types by structure: Ubiquitous (always active), Event-driven (When trigger), State-driven (While state), Unwanted behavior (If condition then), Optional feature (Where feature). Type classification by linguistic pattern, not by content category.

sources.name: IBM Engineering Requirements Management DOORS Next
sources.confidence_description: Credible source, not independently verified
sources.notes: DOORS Next: AI-assisted requirements quality checking via Watson. Manages traceability from requirements through testing. Structured modules, round-trip import/export, baselines, multi-level traceability. Does not provide explicit needs-to-requirements transformation workflow.

sources.name: INCOSE GtWR Review - SE Trends
sources.confidence_description: Credible source, not independently verified
sources.notes: GtWR review: confirms 14 Characteristics (C1-C14), numbered Rules (R1-R36+), numbered Attributes (A1-A15+ confirmed, up to A49 per other sources). A15=Unique Identifier, A2/A3=traceability. Guide focuses on writing not elicitation. Cost-benefit approach to rule application.

sources.name: NASA Appendix C: How to Write a Good Requirement
sources.confidence_description: Verified via authoritative source with citation
sources.notes: NASA guidance: Use TBD for unknown values (minimize), use TBR with rationale/owner/timeline for estimated-but-uncertain values. Requirement types include: functional, performance, interface, environmental, facility, transportation, training, safety, security, design. Quality criteria: clarity, completeness, compliance, consistency, traceability, correctness, verifiability. Mandatory attributes: unique ID, responsible subject, rationale with assumptions, tolerances.

sources.name: INCOSE GtWR 42 Rules Summary - reqi.io
sources.confidence_description: Credible source, not independently verified
sources.notes: Complete list of 42 INCOSE GtWR rules organized by category: Accuracy (R1-R9), Concision (R10-R11), Non-Ambiguity (R12-R17), Singularity (R18-R23), Completeness (R24-R25), Realism (R26), Conditions (R27-R28), Uniqueness (R29-R30), Abstraction (R31), Quantifiers (R32), Tolerance (R33), Quantification (R34-35), Uniformity (R36-40), Modularity (R41-42). Also lists 15 characteristics of quality requirements at individual and set level.

sources.name: Digital Requirements Engineering with INCOSE-derived SysML Meta-model (arxiv 2410.21288)
sources.confidence_description: Verified via authoritative source with citation
sources.notes: Academic paper implementing GtWR v4 in SysML. Confirms 49 Attributes total. Attributes found: A01-Rationale Statement, A08-V&V Primary Method, A10-V&V Level, A15-Unique Identifier, A16-Unique Name, A28-Verification Status, A30-Status, A34-Priority, A38-Key/Driving, A40-Type. Paper notes 'interface requirements, in particular, are rejected by the GtWR' - a critical finding for requirement type handling. Starred attributes indicate mandatory minimum set but full list requires purchase of GtWR document.

sources.name: LLMREI: Automating Requirements Elicitation Interviews with LLMs (arxiv 2507.02564)
sources.confidence_description: Verified via authoritative source with citation
sources.notes: July 2025 paper on LLM-driven requirements elicitation. Key finding: sequential topic-flow questioning outperforms requirement-type-guided questioning. Four question categories: Context-independent (general), Parameterized (templated with context), Context-deepening (follow-ups), Context-enhancing (elaboration). 44.4% of effective questions were context-deepening. Achieves 60.94% full elicitation and 12.76% partial (73.7% recall) in 33 simulated interviews. Does NOT use type-guided ordering - uses contextual topic flow instead.

sources.name: Claude Code Skills Documentation - code.claude.com
sources.confidence_description: Verified via authoritative source with citation
sources.notes: Official Claude Code skills documentation. Key patterns for guided workflows: AskUserQuestion tool for interactive multi-step flows (1-4 questions per call, 2-4 options each); disable-model-invocation:true for user-triggered flows; context:fork for isolated subagent execution; progressive disclosure via 3-level system (metadata ~100 tokens, full skill <5k tokens, referenced files on demand); state-carrying via .local.md files; dynamic context injection via !backtick-command syntax.

sources.name: Plugin-Dev Interactive Commands Reference
sources.confidence_description: Verified via authoritative source with citation
sources.notes: Detailed patterns for AskUserQuestion: Multi-stage workflow (Stage 1 basics -> Stage 2 advanced conditional -> Stage 3 confirmation), Conditional flow branching, Iterative collection (for N items), Validation loop, Incremental configuration building, Dynamic options from context. Progressive disclosure pattern: Quick/Custom/Guided selection then branch. State management via .local.md files. Max 4 questions per AskUserQuestion call, 2-4 options per question.

sources.name: Concept-Dev Plugin Questioning Heuristics Reference
sources.confidence_description: Verified via authoritative source with citation
sources.notes: Documents three questioning modes: Open (spit-ball, 1-2 follow-ups), Metered (phases 2-3, 3-4 questions per turn with checkpoints), Structured (phases 4-5, per-block questions with research validation). Checkpoint format includes summary, gaps, and confirmation. Anti-patterns: question dump (max 4), leading questions, binary railroading, premature narrowing. Structured mode most relevant to requirements elicitation within blocks.

sources.name: LLM Requirements Engineering Systematic Review - Frontiers in Computer Science 2025
sources.confidence_description: Verified via authoritative source with citation
sources.notes: Systematic review of LLMs in requirements engineering. Key findings: Zero-shot (44%) and Few-shot (29%) prompting dominate; RAG (6%) and Interactive prompting (5%) underexplored. Multi-agent systems can generate user stories from needs, assess quality, and prioritize. LLM output is complementary to human expertise. Template-guided generation (provide context + predefined templates -> generate epics/user stories) is an established pattern for needs-to-requirements transformation.

sources.name: NASA Requirements Management Section 6.2
sources.confidence_description: Verified via authoritative source with citation
sources.notes: NASA requirements management guidance. Covers bidirectional traceability (parent-child), CCB change control after Phase A baseline. Does not explicitly detail TBD/TBR tracking (deferred to expanded nen.nasa.gov guidance and RMPs). References TBD/TBR metrics: percent TBD/TBR burn-down (resolution/closure) as a key interface tracking metric.

sources.name: MIL-STD-498 Software Requirements Specification Structure - IX23
sources.confidence_description: Credible source, not independently verified
sources.notes: MIL-STD-498 SRS organizes requirements as: 3.1-3.2 Functional/Capability (states & modes first, then capabilities), 3.3-3.4 Interface (external then internal), 3.5 Data, 3.6/3.12 Constraints, 3.11 Quality/Non-functional (reliability, maintainability etc.), 3.7-3.10/3.13-3.17 Specialized (safety, security, environment, computer resources, personnel). Ordering principle: abstract functional -> concrete technical specifications. States and modes PRECEDE functional requirements in MIL-STD-498.

sources.name: QVscribe INCOSE GtWR Automation Guide (QRA Corp)
sources.confidence_description: Credible source, not independently verified
sources.notes: QVscribe automates INCOSE GtWR rules using NLP; covers passive voice, escape clauses, immeasurable quantification, vague terms, superfluous infinitives. 41-rule set, automates majority. ~50% review time reduction claimed.

sources.name: Automating Requirement Quality Standards with QVscribe (NLP4RE 2020)
sources.confidence_description: Credible source, not independently verified
sources.notes: Academic paper on QVscribe at NLP4RE workshop. Describes NLP techniques for automating INCOSE GfWR compliance including passive voice, escape clauses, vague language detection.

sources.name: Leveraging LLMs for the Quality Assurance of Software Requirements (Lubos et al. 2024)
sources.confidence_description: Verified via authoritative source with citation
sources.notes: Key empirical paper: Llama2-70B evaluated on ISO 29148 characteristics (same as INCOSE C1-C9). DigitalHome project: precision 0.1257, recall 0.7414 (independent); Stopwatch: precision 0.50, recall 0.89. High recall, low precision. Bound assessment improved precision substantially. Human review needed.

sources.name: INCOSE GtWR v4 Complete 42-Rule Guide (reqi.io)
sources.confidence_description: Credible source, not independently verified
sources.notes: Secondary source listing all 42 INCOSE GtWR rules organized by category: Accuracy R1-R9, Concision R10-R11, Non-Ambiguity R12-R17, Singularity R18-R23, Completeness R24-R25, Realism R26, Conditions R27-R28, Uniqueness R29-R30, Abstraction R31, Quantifiers R32, Tolerance R33, Quantification R34-R35, Uniformity R36-R40, Modularity R41-R42. R36-R42 are set-level rules.

sources.name: Digital Requirements Engineering with INCOSE-Derived SysML Meta-Model (Wheaton 2024)
sources.confidence_description: Verified via authoritative source with citation
sources.notes: Confirms C1-C9 for individual requirements (Necessary, Appropriate, Unambiguous, Complete, Singular, Feasible, Verifiable, Correct, Conforming) and C10-C15 for sets (Complete, Consistent, Feasible, Comprehensible, Able-to-be-validated, Correct). R1 Structured Statement contributes to C3, C4, C5, C7, C9. 42 rules total in GtWR v4.

sources.name: INCOSE GtWR V4 Summary Sheet (Official)
sources.confidence_description: Verified via authoritative source with citation
sources.notes: Official INCOSE GtWR v4 summary. Appendix D Rule Applicability Matrix enables users to identify which rules apply. 7-page summary with cross-reference matrices. PDF binary not extractable in this session.

sources.name: On the Impact of Requirements Smells in Prompts (arxiv 2501.04810, 2025)
sources.confidence_description: Verified via authoritative source with citation
sources.notes: Studied 9 smell types: lexical (subjective language, optional parts, weak verbs), syntactic (vague pronouns, passive voice, negative phrases), semantic (logical inconsistencies, numerical discrepancies, ambiguities). GPT-4o clean requirements: 67% LOC precision, 79% recall, 0.68 F1. Semantic smells most harmful. Binary tracing 95-96% accuracy on clean requirements.

sources.name: Automated Smell Detection and Recommendation in NL Requirements - Paska (arxiv 2305.07097)
sources.confidence_description: Verified via authoritative source with citation
sources.notes: Paska tool: NLP + Rimay CNL for smell detection in 2725 annotated industrial requirements. 89% precision and recall for smell detection, 96% precision / 94% recall for recommendations. Industrial case study in financial domain.

sources.name: Natural Language Requirements Testability via Requirement Smells (arxiv 2403.17479)
sources.confidence_description: Verified via authoritative source with citation
sources.notes: 9 requirement smell types detected using neural word-embedding. Improved over Smella: +0.03 precision, +0.33 recall. Polysemy smell detection across 10 domains. Web tool ARTA. MAE 0.12 for testability measurement.

sources.name: Detecting Requirements Defects with NLP Patterns: Railway Domain Industrial Study (Springer 2018)
sources.confidence_description: Verified via authoritative source with citation
sources.notes: Industrial study: 1866 annotated railway requirements. GATE-based NLP patterns. Preliminary: 88.33% recall, 64.24% precision. Large-scale: avg 59% precision, 82% recall with high variation. Discard patterns used to reduce false positives. Two-expert review of FP cases.

sources.name: Improving Requirements Completeness via LLMs - BERT masked LM approach (arxiv 2308.03784)
sources.confidence_description: Verified via authoritative source with citation
sources.notes: BERT MLM for completeness checking. 38% coverage / 12% accuracy at 15 predictions per mask. ML filter (Random Forest/SVM) improves accuracy +36% with -20% coverage. Substantially outperforms TF-IDF and WordNet baselines. Set-level approach for detecting missing terminology.

sources.name: Innoslate Quality Check Feature Documentation
sources.confidence_description: Credible source, not independently verified
sources.notes: Innoslate tool: 6 automated quality checks (Clear, Complete, Consistent, Design-freedom, Traceable, Verifiable) via NLP. 2 manual (Correct, Feasible). Max 75% automated score. Override mechanism allows human judgment. Alert fatigue mitigation via suggestion-not-mandate approach.

sources.name: REUSE Company RQA Quality Studio and RAT Authoring Tool
sources.confidence_description: Credible source, not independently verified
sources.notes: RQA-QUALITY Studio provides automated requirements quality analysis with AI-driven semantic processing. RAT Authoring Tool gives real-time quality checking during authoring using INCOSE GtWR rules. Both integrate with DOORS, Polarion, and other ALM tools.

sources.name: LLMs for Requirements Engineering Survey (arxiv 2509.11446)
sources.confidence_description: Credible source, not independently verified
sources.notes: Survey: Requirements defect detection and classification rank lower in LLM4RE research vs NLP4RE. LLMs evaluated mainly in controlled environments. Elicitation/Validation phase shift creates compliance-critical risks. By 2026 LLM4RE papers may equal total 40-year NLP4RE output.

sources.name: QVscribe 2.10 INCOSE Compliance Release Notes (QRA Corp)
sources.confidence_description: Verified via authoritative source with citation
sources.notes: QVscribe automates 24 of 44 INCOSE rules for requirement statements. Rule Coverage Table groups all 41 rules into: QVscribe-automated, other-tool-automated, manual. Rules not automated are those requiring human judgment (e.g. R41 style guide). Passive voice detection: flags and alerts author to correct.

sources.name: NLP4RE Tools Catalog (GitHub JulianFrattini)
sources.confidence_description: Credible source, not independently verified
sources.notes: Catalog of NLP tools for requirements engineering including QuARS, Smella, NALABS, and others. Useful for comparative landscape of requirements quality checking tools.

sources.name: SEBoK: Technical Performance Measure (TPM) Glossary
sources.confidence_description: Credible source, not independently verified
sources.notes: Authoritative SEBoK TPM definition from Roedler/Jones 2005 and BMP 2012; two-definition entry

sources.name: Systems-Wise: Technical Measures in System Design (MOE/MOP/TPM/KPP hierarchy)
sources.confidence_description: Credible source, not independently verified
sources.notes: Full MOE->MOP->TPM hierarchy with DAU definitions; COI/MOS context; CORE/GENESYS modeling connection

sources.name: INCOSE Technical Performance Measurements (Roedler & Jones, Dec 2005)
sources.confidence_description: Verified via authoritative source with citation
sources.notes: Primary INCOSE TPM guidance document INCOSE-TP-2003-020-01; PDF format; binary not readable via WebFetch

sources.name: JHU EP: Explaining KPPs, KSAs, MOEs, and MOPs
sources.confidence_description: Credible source, not independently verified
sources.notes: Full measurement hierarchy explanation from Johns Hopkins; 403 error on fetch but search engine extracted content

sources.name: DORA: Software Delivery Performance Metrics (Four Keys)
sources.confidence_description: Verified via authoritative source with citation
sources.notes: Official DORA site; five metrics; elite/high tiers defined; deployment frequency, change lead time, change failure rate, failed deployment recovery time, rework rate

sources.name: DORA 2024 Report Highlights (Multitudes analysis)
sources.confidence_description: Credible source, not independently verified
sources.notes: Elite benchmarks: deploy on-demand, lead time <1hr, CFR <5%, recovery <1hr; high: weekly deploy, <1wk lead time

sources.name: Jakob Nielsen: Response Time Limits - NN/G
sources.confidence_description: Verified via authoritative source with citation
sources.notes: Nielsen 3-threshold model: 0.1s instantaneous, 1s uninterrupted flow, 10s attention limit; foundational UX performance research

sources.name: Google RAIL Model: Measure Performance with RAIL (web.dev)
sources.confidence_description: Verified via authoritative source with citation
sources.notes: RAIL: Response 50-100ms, Animation 10ms/frame, Idle 50ms chunks, Load 5s; user perception consequences at each tier; UX-grounded thresholds

sources.name: Google: How Core Web Vitals Thresholds Were Defined (web.dev)
sources.confidence_description: Verified via authoritative source with citation
sources.notes: Methodology: HCI research + CrUX data achievability + device consistency; LCP good<=2500ms poor>4000ms; INP good<=200ms poor>500ms; CLS good<=0.1 poor>0.25; 75th percentile basis

sources.name: WPO Stats: Performance Impact Case Studies (revenue tag)
sources.confidence_description: Verified via authoritative source with citation
sources.notes: Curated case studies: Amazon 1%/100ms, Walmart 2%/1s, Bing 2.8%/1s, Mobify 1.11%/100ms homepage, Zalando 0.7%/100ms, Rakuten 53.4% revenue-per-visitor from CWV improvements

sources.name: SaaS Performance Benchmarking: Industry Standards (Binadox)
sources.confidence_description: Credible source, not independently verified
sources.notes: SaaS benchmarks: response <200ms average, <100ms interactive, p95 <1s; uptime 99.9%/99.99%/99.999%; error rate <0.1% critical; scalability 200-300% traffic spike

sources.name: Wikipedia: Key Performance Parameters (KPP)
sources.confidence_description: Credible source, not independently verified
sources.notes: DoD KPP threshold/objective structure; 3-8 KPPs for ACAT-I; KPPs in CDD/CPD/APB; failure consequences = program reevaluation/termination

sources.name: Innoslate Requirements AI Documentation
sources.confidence_description: Credible source, not independently verified
sources.notes: LLM-based requirement generation/decomposition; generates name, statement, rationale, label; no automated performance target values; aligns with INCOSE GtWR v4

sources.name: arXiv: Automated NFR Generation with LLMs - Comparative Study (2503.15248)
sources.confidence_description: Verified via authoritative source with citation
sources.notes: LLMs automate NFR elicitation >80% cases; gemini-1.5-pro 90.9% accuracy; LLMs do NOT handle numeric targets well; human oversight essential; constraint enforcement in prompting required

sources.name: Uptime.is: SLA Uptime Calculator with Downtime Consequences
sources.confidence_description: Verified via authoritative source with citation
sources.notes: Precise downtime per SLA tier: 99.9%=8h45m/yr, 99.99%=52min/yr, 99.999%=5.26min/yr; mnemonic: 5 nines=5 min/yr

sources.name: INCOSE Systems Engineering Measurement Primer v2.0
sources.confidence_description: Verified via authoritative source with citation
sources.notes: Comprehensive measurement framework; covers MOE, MOP, TPM, KPP definitions and relationships; PDF - search engine extracted content

sources.name: HandWiki: Key Performance Parameters - Engineering
sources.confidence_description: Credible source, not independently verified
sources.notes: Threshold=minimum acceptable at low-moderate risk; Objective=desired goal at higher risk; ACAT-I requires 3-8 KPPs; failure triggers program reevaluation

sources.name: INCOSE Guide to Writing Requirements V4 Summary Sheet
sources.confidence_description: Verified via authoritative source with citation
sources.notes: Rule R34 measurable performance; eliminate subjective words; use at-least/no-more-than/within-X-seconds constructs; verifiability requirement

sources.name: INCOSE GtWR V4 Summary Sheet
sources.confidence_description: Verified via authoritative source with citation
sources.notes: Primary source for GtWR attributes A1-A49 including A2 trace-to-parent, A3 trace-to-source, A6 success criteria, A7 strategy, A8 verification method, A9 responsible org. PDF not directly parseable but confirmed via search synthesis.

sources.name: INCOSE GtWR V3.1 Summary Sheet
sources.confidence_description: Verified via authoritative source with citation
sources.notes: V3.1 version of GtWR attributes; consistent with V4 on A2 parent trace, A3 source trace, A6-A9 V&V attributes.

sources.name: Digital Requirements Engineering with INCOSE-Derived SysML Meta-Model (Wheaton 2024)
sources.confidence_description: Verified via authoritative source with citation
sources.notes: Arxiv paper confirming 49 GtWR attributes and 42 rules. Names A08 as System V&V Primary Method, A01 as Rationale Statement. Confirms attribute count and some codes.

sources.name: SEBoK System Verification wiki page
sources.confidence_description: Verified via authoritative source with citation
sources.notes: SEBoK defines six verification methods: inspection, analysis, analogy/similarity, demonstration, test, sampling. Provides guidance on which method applies to which artifact type.

sources.name: INCOSE NRM — V&V Across the Lifecycle (2024)
sources.confidence_description: Credible source, not independently verified
sources.notes: 2024 INCOSE presentation on NRM V&V lifecycle. PDF not directly parseable. Confirmed via search to cover success criteria, method, strategy, responsible org attributes.

sources.name: INCOSE System Requirements Traceability (process model)
sources.confidence_description: Verified via authoritative source with citation
sources.notes: INCOSE process model definition of system requirements traceability including bidirectional traceability requirements.

sources.name: OMG Requirements Interchange Format (ReqIF) v1.2
sources.confidence_description: Verified via authoritative source with citation
sources.notes: OMG standard XML-based format for requirements interchange. SpecObject with user-defined attributes, REQ-IF XML schema. Supported by nearly all RM tools. Not JSON-native but foundational standard.

sources.name: OSLC Requirements Management Specification v2.0
sources.confidence_description: Verified via authoritative source with citation
sources.notes: OSLC RM defines RDF/JSON linked data schema for requirements. oslc_rm:Requirement resources with typed links. JSON-LD representation. Enables machine-readable bidirectional traceability over HTTP.

sources.name: ReqView Requirements Traceability Links Documentation
sources.confidence_description: Verified via authoritative source with citation
sources.notes: Concrete JSON schema for requirements traceability links. linkTypeId, name, source/target role names. Example: test link (Tests / Tested by), satisfaction link (Satisfies / Satisfied by). Human-readable JSON format for version control integration.

sources.name: Innoslate Traceability Matrix Overview
sources.confidence_description: Credible source, not independently verified
sources.notes: Innoslate traceability matrix: interactive X-Y grid, relationship creation by cell click. Export formats: XLSX, CSV, importable CSV. Configures axes by hierarchy, query, or related entity.

sources.name: Qualicen: How to Find Semantic Duplicates in Requirements
sources.confidence_description: Credible source, not independently verified
sources.notes: NLP pipeline for duplicate detection: tokenization, stemming, stop-word removal, n-gram (2-gram, 3-gram) creation, cosine similarity. Configurable threshold. Defines 'semantic smells' as redundant requirements from copy-paste.

sources.name: IREB RE Magazine: Automated Quality Assurance for Requirements
sources.confidence_description: Verified via authoritative source with citation
sources.notes: Describes ~40 automated rule checks: completeness, consistency, traceability, structural conformance. Tools: SoftAudit, RAT, IBM Requirements Assistant, QuARS. Feedback to authors has educational purpose. XML model output enables cross-document validation.

sources.name: IEEE/ISO/IEC 29119 Software Testing Standards Series
sources.confidence_description: Verified via authoritative source with citation
sources.notes: ISO/IEC/IEEE 29119-3 defines test documentation templates including test completion criteria, coverage measures, exit criteria patterns. Part 4 defines test design techniques (spec-, structure-, experience-based).

sources.name: ISTQB CTFL Syllabus — Test Basis and Testware Traceability
sources.confidence_description: Verified via authoritative source with citation
sources.notes: ISTQB defines traceability between test basis (requirements) and testware (test cases, results). Coverage criteria as KPIs. Exit criteria: coverage rate, error count, success percentages.

sources.name: INCOSE Requirements Completeness: A Deterministic Approach (Carson 1998)
sources.confidence_description: Verified via authoritative source with citation
sources.notes: Three-step completeness method: (1) identify all system interfaces, (2) analyze interfaces to derive requirements, (3) verify completeness via complementary antecedents. Interface identification is foundational to completeness.

sources.name: Siamese Neural Networks for Semantic Requirements Similarity (IEEE 2024)
sources.confidence_description: Verified via authoritative source with citation
sources.notes: SNN + sentence Transformer (LLM) + LSTM with backward network layer for measuring semantic similarity between requirements. State of the art for duplicate/overlap detection.

sources.name: INCOSE Visure Solutions Guide to Writing Requirements Overview
sources.confidence_description: Credible source, not independently verified
sources.notes: Secondary source confirming INCOSE verification methods (inspection, analysis, demonstration, testing) and quality characteristics. Confirms bidirectional traceability and RTM linkage concepts.

sources.name: Jama Connect Live Traceability features
sources.confidence_description: Credible source, not independently verified
sources.notes: Jama Connect Live Traceability: real-time cross-document consistency, impact analysis on change, coverage visualization. Integrates with DOORS for cross-tool validation.

sources.name: ISO/IEC 25010:2023 Product Quality Model — arc42 Overview
sources.confidence_description: Verified via authoritative source with citation
sources.notes: Lists all 9 quality characteristics: Functional Suitability, Performance Efficiency, Compatibility, Interaction Capability, Reliability, Security, Maintainability, Flexibility, Safety — directly maps to cross-cutting NFR sweep categories

sources.name: AltexSoft — Non-Functional Requirements: Categories and Examples
sources.confidence_description: Credible source, not independently verified
sources.notes: Lists 9 core NFR categories: performance, scalability, portability, compatibility, reliability, availability, maintainability, security, usability — practical taxonomy for cross-cutting sweep

sources.name: SEBoK — System Requirements Definition
sources.confidence_description: Verified via authoritative source with citation
sources.notes: SEBoK's 5 requirement categories: Function/Performance, Fit/Operational, Form, Quality, Compliance. Also covers allocation as assigning requirements to lower physical architecture level with budgeting

sources.name: INCOSE Requirements Working Group — NRM Section 6 Overview
sources.confidence_description: Verified via authoritative source with citation
sources.notes: URL returned 404 during fetch but document referenced authoritatively in multiple INCOSE sources as covering requirements allocation process. Allocation defined as assigning system-level requirements to next-lower physical architecture elements.

sources.name: Stell Engineering — Metrics for Requirements Management
sources.confidence_description: Credible source, not independently verified
sources.notes: Coverage metric: verifies all stakeholder goals, system-level functions, and technical specs are captured. Completeness metric: checks requirements are specific, testable, measurable.

sources.name: ReqView — ISO/IEC/IEEE 29148 SRS Template Documentation
sources.confidence_description: Verified via authoritative source with citation
sources.notes: IEEE 29148 defines StRS, SyRS, SRS, BRS, OpsCon document types. SRS sections include Introduction, Product Overview, Verification, and functional/non-functional requirement areas.

sources.name: MIL-STD-498 SRS Sections — ix23.com
sources.confidence_description: Verified via authoritative source with citation
sources.notes: Full MIL-STD-498 SRS structure: Scope, References, Requirements (3.1-3.18 including capability, interfaces, safety, security, environment, computer resources, quality factors, constraints, personnel, logistics), Qualification Provisions, Traceability, Notes, Appendixes

sources.name: Jama Software — RTM Definition and Purpose
sources.confidence_description: Credible source, not independently verified
sources.notes: Standard RTM columns: Requirement ID, Description, Test Case ID, Validation Status, Compliance Reference. Three RTM types: forward, backward, bidirectional traceability.

sources.name: Advanced Navigation — Verification Cross Reference Matrix (VCRM)
sources.confidence_description: Credible source, not independently verified
sources.notes: VCRM is final output of acceptance testing. Contains: product requirements, associated test plans, test reports, pass/fail status per requirement. Traceability between requirements and verification evidence.

sources.name: NASA — Appendix D Requirements Verification Matrix
sources.confidence_description: Verified via authoritative source with citation
sources.notes: NASA RVM format: unique identifier per 'shall' requirement, source document, verification approach. Matrix may be split by requirements document. Only 'shall' requirements included.

sources.name: SEBoK — Applying Life Cycle Processes (Recursive Application)
sources.confidence_description: Verified via authoritative source with citation
sources.notes: SE processes apply recursively because 'system' is recursive. Same System Definition processes repeat at each decomposition level. This is the foundational justification for re-entrant process design in Block 11.

sources.name: NASA — 4.3 Logical Decomposition
sources.confidence_description: Verified via authoritative source with citation
sources.notes: NASA logical decomposition: (1) define logical models, (2) allocate requirements and resolve conflicts via iterative functional analysis, (3) capture work products. Inputs: validated requirements. Outputs: logical decomposition models, derived technical requirements.

sources.name: Reqi.io — INCOSE Requirements Quality: 42-Rule Guide
sources.confidence_description: Credible source, not independently verified
sources.notes: INCOSE 42 rules organized in 14 categories. Key set-level quality: complete, consistent, feasible, comprehensible, correct. Cross-cutting rules: R29-R30 (uniqueness), R36-R40 (language consistency), R41-R42 (modularity/structure).

sources.name: arXiv — Improving Requirements Completeness via LLMs (2308.03784)
sources.confidence_description: Credible source, not independently verified
sources.notes: BERT-based method for external completeness checking: masks nouns/verbs, predicts missing terminology using external knowledge. Focuses on terminology gaps, not goal coverage. ML classifier with 13 features (POS, semantic similarity, TF-IDF) filters predictions.

sources.name: Reqi.io — Requirements Allocation in Systems Engineering
sources.confidence_description: Credible source, not independently verified
sources.notes: Allocation steps: derive measurable requirements, decompose/derive, manage constraints, link traceability. Decision patterns: collaborative workshops, trade-off analysis, iterative refinement. Emerging: AI-powered allocation tools.

sources.name: OMG ReqIF 1.2 — Requirements Interchange Format Standard
sources.confidence_description: Verified via authoritative source with citation
sources.notes: ReqIF is XML-based open standard for machine-readable requirements exchange between tools. Supports hierarchical requirements, all attributes and links, loss-free interchange. Some tools also use JSON for configuration.

sources.name: concept-dev plugin — concept.document.md command (Phase 5)
sources.confidence_description: Verified via authoritative source with citation
sources.notes: Established pattern: section-by-section generation with approval gate, mandatory assumption review before generation, skeptic agent invoked on solution landscape, two deliverables (CONCEPT-DOCUMENT.md + SOLUTION-LANDSCAPE.md), finalize via pass-gate command

sources.name: concept-dev plugin — solution-landscape.md template
sources.confidence_description: Verified via authoritative source with citation
sources.notes: Template pattern: per-domain approach table (Approach, Maturity, Description, Pros, Cons, Sources, Confidence), Cross-Cutting Considerations section, Unresolved Gaps table with priority, Skeptic Review Summary table, Source Bibliography by confidence level

gaps.description: No proven pattern for LLM-based extraction of needs candidates from markdown concept documents
State.json schema for requirements-dev needs to be designed - what phases, what counters, what additional fields beyond concept-dev
Need statement patterns for software systems — standard INCOSE examples are often hardware-centric
Which subset of GtWR rules apply at needs level vs only at requirements level
Cannot access full GtWR v4 PDF - complete mandatory attribute list (A01-A49 starred set) not publicly available
required_for: Block Requirements Engine mandatory attribute elicitation

gaps.description: INCOSE NRM specific needs-to-requirements transformation procedural steps not publicly accessible (paid publication)
No precedent found for fixed type-sequence elicitation (functional then performance then interface then constraint then quality) in existing tools or standards
Complete GtWR v4 mandatory attribute list (A01-A49 with starred designations)
INCOSE NRM specific needs-transformation steps and type-ordering rationale
required_for: Block Requirements Engine needs seeding logic

gaps.description: Empirical evidence for optimal requirement type ordering (functional->performance->interface->constraint->quality)
TBD/TBR closure tracking schema and resolution workflow standards
required_for: Block Requirements Engine TBX tracking implementation

gaps.description: QVscribe exact rule coverage table: which of 42 GtWR rules are automated vs manual is described in a PDF (edu.qracorp.com) that was not readable in this session. The exact count of 24 automated rules cited in the task brief was not independently confirmed.

INCOSE GtWR v4 Appendix D Rule Applicability Matrix full details: the PDF is a paywalled/binary document. Secondary sources confirm it exists and maps rules to needs vs requirements applicability and identifies which rules need a project data dictionary, but specific rule-by-rule matrix content was not retrievable.

Per-rule precision/recall metrics for automated INCOSE GtWR rule checking: no published empirical study was found that reports per-rule accuracy for individual checks like passive voice, escape clauses, vague terms, etc. The Lubos 2024 paper reports aggregate precision/recall across all 9 ISO 29148 characteristics but not per-rule.

Set-level C10-C15 automatable methods: research shows BERT-based completeness (C10) is partially automatable at ~38% coverage, NLP patterns can detect some consistency issues (C11), formal methods can check feasibility/realizability (C12). However, no comprehensive tool or study addresses all 6 set characteristics in an integrated way with known accuracy rates.
INCOSE NRM (Needs, Requirements, and Measures) - specific NRM document guidance on TPMs distinct from SE Handbook
Roedler & Jones 2005 INCOSE-TP-2003-020-01 full text - PDF was binary-unreadable; contains most complete TPM selection/establishment guidance

Academic RE tools literature: no evidence found of any requirements tool providing automated performance target value recommendations from industry benchmarks - gap between RE tool capabilities and benchmark-assisted target setting

DORA medium and low tier numeric benchmarks - official 2024 DORA report document contains page 13 benchmark table but full report behind registration wall; medium/low thresholds not found in accessible sources

NASA NASA-SP-2016-6105 SE Handbook chapter on TPM tracking and threshold/objective consequence analysis - PDF accessible but chapter-level extraction needed; full consequence analysis procedure not extracted
Full INCOSE GtWR v4 attribute table (all 49 attributes with definitions) — PDF paywall prevents extraction of complete A1-A49 list with descriptions

Normative definition of GtWR attribute numbering A6-A9 vs A08 discrepancy — search synthesis gives A6=success criteria, A7=strategy, A8=method, A9=responsible org but arxiv paper codes A08=method; exact numbering scheme needs primary source verification

Standard requirement-type-to-verification-method mapping table — no public document found that authoritatively maps functional/performance/interface/constraint requirement types to recommended V&V method
OSLC RM v2 full resource shape properties — archive URL (404) prevented reading actual oslc_rm:Requirement attribute list and link type definitions; current OSLC v3 spec location unclear
INCOSE NRM traceability presentation (Nov 2024) — PDF returned 404; this appeared to be the most current INCOSE guidance on traceability completeness criteria and machine-readable formats

Similarity threshold benchmarks for requirements duplicate detection — no public authoritative source gives a recommended cosine similarity threshold value for classifying requirements as duplicates vs. related
INCOSE NRM Section 6.4 specific allocation methods — document returned 404 and PDF was unreadable binary. Exact subsection structure of NRM Ch.6 on allocation is unverified from primary source.
Requirements Allocation Sheet (RAS) exact column format — DoD DID-GDRQ-81222 is paywalled/requires login. Exact RAS column names unverified from primary source.

IEEE 29148 full SRS section list — reqview.com template page returned CSS-only content. Full section hierarchy unverified from primary source. MIL-STD-498 sections were retrievable as partial substitute.

Goal-level completeness checking methods — research found terminology completeness (BERT-based) and coverage metrics, but no authoritative method for checking that requirements cover ALL stated success criteria / user goals at the semantic level. This is an open research problem.
INCOSE NRM Section 15 (Management) content — fetched URL pointed to Section 14 (NRVV Management), not Section 15. NRM management chapter content unread.
